contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox IPA |ipa number=312 |decimal=630 |x-sampa=& |kirshenbaum=a. |imagefile=Open front rounded vowel (vector).svg |imagesize=150px }} The '''open front rounded vowel''', or '''low front rounded vowel''', is a type of [[vowel]] sound, not confirmed to be [[phonemic]] in any [[Speech communication|spoken]] [[language]]s. The symbol in the [[International Phonetic Alphabet]] that represents this sound is ⟨{{IPA|ɶ}}⟩, and the equivalent [[X-SAMPA]] symbol is <tt>&</tt>. The letter ⟨{{IPA|ɶ}}⟩ is a [[small caps]] rendition of ⟨[[OE ligature|Œ]]⟩. Note that ⟨{{IPA|œ}}⟩, the lowercase version of the ligature, is used for the [[open-mid front rounded vowel]]. The IPA prefers terms "close" and "open" for vowels, and the name of the article follows this. However, a large number of linguists, perhaps a majority, prefer the terms "high" and "low", and these are the only terms found in introductory textbooks on [[phonetics]] such as those by [[Peter Ladefoged]]. ==Features== {{IPA chart vowels}} {{open vowel}} {{front vowel}} {{rounded vowel}} {{clear}} ==Occurrence== {{IPA|[ɶ]}} is not confirmed to exist as a phoneme in any language. A phoneme generally transcribed by this symbol is reported from the [[Amstetten, Lower Austria|Amstetten]] dialect of [[Austro-Bavarian]] German. It is the rounded equivalent of {{IPA|/æ/}}, not of open {{IPA|/a/}}, and so would be more narrowly transcribed as {{IPA|[œ̞]}} or {{IPA|[ɶ̝]}}. However, the vowel [[formant]]s place Amstetten {{IPA|/æ/}} and {{IPA|/œ/}} one third of the way between {{IPA|/a/}} and {{IPA|/i/}}, matching the IPA definition for [[open-mid vowel]]s. {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="2" | Language !! Word !! [[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]]!! Meaning !! Notes |- | colspan="2" | [[Danish language|Danish]]<ref>{{harvcoltxt|Grønnum|1998|pp=101–101}}</ref> || {{Lang|da|''[[Danish alphabet|b'''ø'''rn]]''}} || {{IPA|[bɶ̝ɐ̯n]}}|| 'children'|| Near-open. See [[Danish phonology]] |- | rowspan="2" | [[French language|French]] ||[[Acadian French|Acadian]] ||rowspan="2" | {{Lang|fr|''[[French orthography|honn'''eu'''r]]''}} ||rowspan="2" | {{IPA|[ɔnɶ̝ʀ]}}||rowspan="2" | 'honour' || rowspan="2"|Allophone of {{IPA|/œ/}} before {{IPA|/ʀ/}}. See [[Quebec French phonology]] |- |[[Quebec French|Quebec]] |- | [[Austro-Bavarian]] ||[[Amstetten, Lower Austria|Amstetten]] dialect || {{Lang|de|[[German orthography|''S'''eil''''']]}} || {{IPA|[sɶ̝ː]}}|| 'rope'|| See [[German phonology]] |- | colspan="2" | [[Swedish language|Swedish]]{{citation needed|date=May 2013}} || {{Lang|sv|''[[Swedish alphabet|h'''ö'''rt]]''}} || {{IPA|[hɶ̝ːʈ]}}|| 'heard' ([[supine]])|| See [[Swedish phonology]] |} ==See also== * [[Index of phonetics articles]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Bibliography== {{refbegin}} * {{citation |last=Grønnum |first=Nina |year=1998 |title=Danish |journal=Journal of the International Phonetic Association |volume=28 |issue=1–­2 |pages=99–105 |doi=10.1017/S0025100300006290 }} {{refend}} {{IPA navigation}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Open Front Rounded Vowel}} [[Category:Vowels]]
